scenes.location: FIRE STATION 17 STORAGE ROOM 20 YRS. EARLIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. Then the GLINT of a flashlight. Its beam rocks  crazily to and fro across the inside of a small storage r as we hear two children arguing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing it wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing it wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard, but we get a sense of the room in the whipping beam of light. Huge, dark coats lined up like sides of be on steel batons. Bent, stained helmets hung like African  masks. Beneath them BRIAN, 7, and STEPHEN, 12, are trying to str into a pair of the ludicrously massive coats over their  pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't go like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who asked you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you do it like that it'll open in  the fire. Then you'll get burned and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door suddenly opens, morning sunlight roaring in. It' fire station storage room full of fire gear. A fireman st in the doorway, tall, athletic, their father; DENNIS  McCAFFREY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's going to die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian. He's not doing it right, dad.  He never does it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gestures for them to  come out) Well, let's have a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two boys tromp out of the closet. The rubber turn-out boots are as high as their thighs. The ends of the coats  drag on the floor. They salute, Brian's arm just an empty sleeve. Dennis kneels down and re-fastens Brian's coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother's right. If you don't  fasten these correctly they could  open and you'd get burned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And DIE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't let me die, would you,  Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaffreys are smarter than fire,  Brian. (playfully slaps their  shoulders) How 'bout lunch, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fireman shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's with the mouth? Where'd  you grow up, a barn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- The station suddenly fills with the BELLOW of an ALARM KLAXON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Never fails...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young fireman, ADCOX, appears with the dispatch card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medium deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to come along, Brian? Watch the  old man earn his keep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed) Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've come along a dozen times,  Stephen, give your brother a chance.  We'll be back in a few minutes. (to Brian) How 'bout it, sport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis scoops Brian up and loads him into the fire engine cab. The other three firemen climb aboard and take their  places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a cough of diesel, a crunch of gears, and the eng is pulling out of the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit the button, Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian stamps his foot on the siren button. The red light  snaps on, the siren growls and blares, and they're off do the street. Brian turns around in his seat and, at the la instant before the corner, makes eye contact with his old brother. They stick their tongues out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engine howls its way through the city. Brian, sandwic between his father and Adcox, looks out in wonderment at  intersections zipping past like picket fences, at people sidewalks holding hands over their ears, at the red emerg lights bouncing crazily off shop windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lazy smoke curls out the second story of a commercial blo Medium deal. The engine pulls up and the firemen are jump off like ship rats. Dennis opens his door, hops down, and pauses just long enough to point a serious finger at his  son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay near the truck. (winks) And keep an eye out for us, huh?  We're short handed today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian nods vigorously, taking the command seriously. Denn smiles and is off, dragging a hoseline with his crew towa a doorway they disappear into. Brian climbs down from the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stray too far, little man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian smiles to the pumper operator. He just wants a bett look. And he gets it: Smoke turned evil and dark now, tak on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a level of apartments above the storefronts. As B watches, a window opens and out steps his father and Adco onto a small fire escape. Their attention's on the next w over, out of reach, wrapped in leaky smoke. Suddenly Dennis climbs up onto the fire escape railing, a with only an axe, and JUMPS across to the next metal balc A ballsy, dangerous move. He kicks in the window, breaks the frame with his axe, and dives in. A beat later he reemerges on the balcony with a terrified smudged little girl. He hands the little girl over the ra to a fireman now coming up the more traditional way -- a  ladder. Dennis's face lifts and grins at Brian; dirty, bigger tha life, invincible. He winks a wink only possible between  fathers and sons and he's gone again, back into the swirl darkness. As Brian stands there, full of love, full of pr he sees a piece of awning along the roofline crack; relea a sickly yellow tongue of flame that slinks over the roof The flame seems to pause, to stare at Brian a beat. Shhh, don't tell anyone. Brian is transfixed, his little head  staring up in astonishment. Nobody else has noticed it. Brian can see his father and Adcox through the window;  probing, looking for the flame lurking just above. Brian  starts to call out in a small, hesitant voice,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to call louder... But suddenly everything is  happening very fast in slow motion: -- Brian can see Adcox testing the ceiling with a pike po as Brian steps forward, under the power of a flame that  beckons him as --  Dennis suddenly THROWS his body against Adcox, knocking h clear just as a flame EXPLODES DOWNWARD from the ceiling  fully against him as -- All the building's windows BLOW O and it's like the sky's erupted for Brian, a burning hail that falls and pelts the ground around him. Plaster, wood and something metal that cracks against the pavement and  spins slowly. A fire helmet. And Adcox is coming out the door now, blackened and torn, hopeless tears streaming down his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get us some backup! We need some  goddamn backup!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, spotting Brian, he runs towards him. And the helmet  spins and spins and Adcox keeps running, and the sky is  raining fire, and the flame on the roof has risen up now its full, horrifying size and it's laughing now, laughing the little boy as the helmet finally stops spinning, and read the printing on the neck guard.

dialogues.speaker: MCCAFFREY
dialogues.text: And Adcox is sobbing and has his arms around the boy,  protecting him from the fire, the world, but it's like Br doesn't see him. He pulls away from Adcox, walks up to hi father's helmet, And puts it on. The scene EXPLODES with a flash as a photographer capture the instant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on the freeze-frame. Let it become an aged cover of  LIFE. The magazine jiggles and rocks and we see now it's  sitting atop a box of knick-knacks jostling in the back s of an aging BMW. There's plenty of other boxes here, a li on the move, and in the driver's seat, BRIAN McCAFFREY, n 27. There's piles of empty burger wrappers, Coke cans, an Florida knick-knacks on the dash board; a little blow-up  palm tree, a cheesy hula girl emblazoned with "McCaffrey  High-End Stereo Sales".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian and his battered BMW shoot past prairie, cow countr nervous suburbs and finally a sign: WELCOME TO CHICAGO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wind tugging at his bangs, Brian stares down at the grave of Dennis and Mary Elizabeth McCaffrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a crusty sink he combs his hair, knots a tie around hi neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian walks through its sculpted columns, straightening h tie. He comes to a door, FIRE ACADEMY CHIEF. He takes a d breath, steadies his gaze, and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ACADEMY CHIEF sits at his desk going over a file. Out the window can be heard a FIRE TRAINING CLASS in action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian's sitting in the seat opposite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it was a joke, sir, you'd be  laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You walked out on this academy six  years ago. One week to graduation.  You think we forgot that? You think  I did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want another shot, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Look, everybody remembers your old  man. Being his son, all you had to  do was breathe to graduate here.  Dead Hero Father Rule. But you blew  us off. Why should I take you back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you remember, sir, my test scores  were in the top --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I don't give a damn what your  test scores were, maybe you could  have been a good firemen, but you  had your shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need another one, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, but it's out of my hands. Try  again next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it isn't out of your hands or  you wouldn't even have met me. If I  push you have to let me back in.  Dead Hero Father Rule. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simmers) Even if you graduate this academy,  you've still got nine months of  probation. That's hard duty, son. If  you don't really love this job, it'll  kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rises) See you Monday. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we hear the BLOW OF A WHISTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And everybody lined up at attention in dress blues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at podium) Though the world changes every day,  some things are truly forever:  Courage, devotion, and honor in what  we do. This class is a special one,  for we dedicate it to the three  firefighters that have fallen this  year: Donald Knowlton, Richard Walter  and Michael Petzold... (silent beat) Ladies and gentlemen, it is with  pleasure that I certify that Candidate  Class number 322, having successfully  completed all academy requirements,  are hereby graduated to the Chicago  Fire Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candidates and their relatives CHEER and leap to their fe Something struggles inside of Brian. He doesn't stand at  first. Another Candidate, TIM, 20, looks at him strangely So does the Academy Chief, his eyes finding Brian's. And  Brian's standing slowly now, joining them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An expensive one. We hear a window BREAK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the dimness a file cabinet. An AXE SUDDENLY SLAMS into it, RIPPING it apart. Files crash to the floor. And picture. 1970. Four young guys marlin fishing. Time of th lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a GREY PUTTY being SLAPPED along the edges of a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A split-level firemen's dive; complete with mounted axes personalized T-shirts from various engine companies proud declaring "LADDER CO. 6 -- AXE FIRST, HOSE LATER" and "CH FD, 150 YEARS OF TRADITION UNIMPEDED BY PROGRESS". Tonight the place is firmly in the hands of an army of  recently graduated candidates. A few on the back patio ha hooked up a charged hoseline and are taking potshots at  balloon targets, each other, the neighbor's cat. Brian an Tim, still in their uniforms, enter from the street. Surv the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Completely out of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are we waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they shoulder their way inside, another CANDIDATE appe holding proudly a fistful of sealed envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot off the presses, guys. Station  assignments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim and everyone else but Brian eagerly tear into them. B nonchalantly shoulders up to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beer, Willy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barkeep turns and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it isn't the littlest  McCaffrey. (to candidates with  hose) Hey! You break anything with that  you buy it! (to Brian) Sorry, there must be something wrong  with my eyes. I keep thinking that's  a fire department uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in my blood, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The candidates are ripping open their assignments, exclai to each other: "All right! Engine 117! That's a slum! The get cookers every day!". "Oh no, Engine 10, that's a nice neighborhood"... Willy turns to the bulletin board behind him and unpins a stack of business cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. Well, let's have a look at  what else was "in your blood". I  always look forward to getting these,  they make such a nice collage for  the bar... "Assistant Director, Sales,  Aspen Snowmobile Tours..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't offer the kinda growth and  challenge I need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh. And "Pioneer's Pride, Mobile  Log Cabins". That was in your blood  about six months wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Management were pin heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Laguna Jamming, Custom Surfboards"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee sucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just this year, "Brian's Sound  Spectrum". Your own company even.  Big step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was ahead of my time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I've got a perfect little  spot here for "Brian McCaffrey,  Fireman"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim holds an envelope marked McCAFFREY out to Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you even curious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engine 115, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opens it, surprised) How'd you know? These are supposed  to be sealed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky guess. (winks) And a case of scotch to a captain in  station assignments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You crooked son of a bitch. Why 115?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of fires. They promote faster  there. Take a look at the last Lt.'s  list, half the guys on it came from  that battalion. Gotta think about  your future, Timmy. 115's the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah man, if you're gonna bribe your  way into a station, why not 17 with  me and your brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Brian's reaction

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Porsche knifes through darkened streets. The DRIVER, 50 is dressed for success. Pulling up to the brownstone we s earlier, he gets out and rubs his eyes. Another day in th salt mines. Climbing the short stairs, he sticks his key into the loc and opens the door. It is the last thing he will ever do. A THUNDERING EXPLOSION ENGULFS the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is packed now with girls flirting with the  candidates, putting their helmets on, etc. The horseplay  around the bar suddenly stops at the sweet sound of a SIR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone steps outside, cocks an ear. And here it comes, real thing, SCREECHING past in a full-tilt rush. Shouts a raised toasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that's my cousin's company!  C'mon! Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Brian turns, he suddenly confronted by an elderly  LITHUANIAN WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Mrs. Viatkus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs his cheeks and rattles off in Lithuanian. Brian can only smile. Then two attractive jean-clad legs step u JENNIFER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Jennifer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... I've been sorta keeping a low  profile... the academy... I graduated  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... I see you're still in the  neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite. Just visiting. I live in  Lincoln Park now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What have you been up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work for city hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you think I just dried up and  blew away when you left? The world  does turn once in awhile Brian, even  without your permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, Tim OPENS UP the hoseline, DRENCHING Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't want you overheating, Brian!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian ducks the stream and PULLS a length of hose near hi feet, FLIPPING Tim. Brian JUMPS him, shuts off the hose a pins him to the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay okay! Uncle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian walks back toward Jennifer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've certainly matured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if nothing else, it's nice to  know we can still be friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be your friend, Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another in a series of fire engines HOWL past. Tim grabs  Brian by the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian and Tim jump into Brian's car. They shoot blindly d the street looking for the fire engine, running down red  lights or anything else that gets in their way. Brian sud hits the brakes, SCREECHING to a stop. They roll down the windows. Far off can be heard the wind-up of a siren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points) That way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCREECH. They fly around a corner, down a block, and ther it is, lights flashing up ahead. Brian GUNS it, roars up  alongside the fire engine. Tim leans out the window, shak a bottle of beer, and lets loose a foamy eruption in the  truck driver's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim! You crazy motherfucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'cha got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Box alarm. Walton Ave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll meet ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Brian and Tim pull up two engine companies are already dragging lines toward the rolling brownstone we saw explo earlier. Tim cheers the firemen on like a drive-in movie. Brian watches the fire with uneasy fascination. Embers  whipping into the night, drifting to the ground around hi One of the engine companies is entering the doorway now. watches as they willingly crawl into a place any sane per would run for their life from. Jesus Christ. FLASH -- Bri turns at the blinding snap of a camera. Several locals ar gathered around a parked car, some taking pictures. Brian notices that right away. It takes a beat longer to notice the CHARRED CORPSE stuffed head-first through the windshi It's the Porsche driver, his legs sticking out at crazy  angles. A dog barks furiously at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also looking at body) Man. Something sure put a crimp in  his evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Backdraft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brownstone fire quickly transforms itself into noisy  clouds of dirty white steam. And one of the firemen is co back out now, walking toward Brian. When he's just a few yards away he pulls off his air mask and helmet and we shudder with Brian, because the man is dead ringer for HIS FATHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look what we have here. Nice  costume. Rent it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to thank you for coming to my  graduation, Stephen. It was a great  inspiration to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're going to fight fires now,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pats Brian's cheeks, leaving behind large charcoal sme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re smears) Doesn't work on you. (turns to leave) See ya around, little brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not likely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns) Well, see you're wrong already. Had  a talk with Chief Fitzgerald, and we  decided in the interest of brotherly  love, that maybe you shouldn't be  way over on the other side of town.  So starting tomorrow, your assigned  to company 17. My company. (Brian's color drops  a hue) One case of scotch, you're getting  cheap in your old age, Brian...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Stephen turns for his own men, Tim staring at Brian a clouds of smoke drift past like ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flame LEAPS up into the foreground. Touches a cigarette The cigarette glows, lingers, then lowers slowly from the mouth of RIMGALE, fifty-five years old and six and a half feet of solid granite. Wearing a windbreaker and grey sla tucked into fire department rubber boots, he takes anothe slow drag. Looks at the body stuffed into the windshield. It's twenty yards away from the brownstone. Stephen looks as Rimgale drops the cigarette, crushes it with his boot, and crosses the street to the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charred walls hiss and snap in the steamy darkness. Rimga is there, gloomy in the beam of his flashlight. He crouch down, plays his flashlight along the ruined baseboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you stare any longer Stevie, I'll  start charging you admission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen is leaning in the doorway, watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a cause?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are the glory boys actually showing  interest in Investigation's work? I  may have a stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glory boys just want to finish  their report so they can go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rimgale's flashlight finds a wall socket that he pries lo and holds up to the light. He lowers it, takes in the wal the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gonna have to wait a few  days on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim's talking to his cousin. Brian hangs back, watches th body-bag people load the Porsche driver into a meat wagon There's a still an audience for this, still stray dogs  circling and barking. Brian walks up, looks inside the ca and sees on a seat the ragged remains of a FINGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to coroner crew) Hey, you forgot... this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're already climbing into the wagon. The driver smile creepily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We always leave something for the  dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian looks across the fireground, sees his brother walki back to the fire engine. They share a brief, edgy glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest one. South-side Irish old fashioned. Brian walks up. There's a little kid, about five, playing with a toy  fire truck on the drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sean. What's goin' on, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid stares at him without a glimmer of recognition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Uncle Brian. Y'know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes his hand into a talking puppet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bandito accent) "Spinach? We don't need no stinking  spinach". Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid drops his toy truck and flees inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom! Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian follows, sticks his head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hellooo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A warm looking woman, 30's, HELEN, comes around the corne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Helen. Man, you look great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like... Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a tentative hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bout written you off. How long have  you been in town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four months?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know, Should'a called.  I've been really busy. I joined the  fire department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen's expression suddenly saddens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Brian... (beat) You guys... you really know how to  put each other through it, don't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little kid is peeking fearfully from the kitchen door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Sean? Jeez, he's a giant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you'd be surprised what three  years can do to a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean, come on out, man. What, you  forget your favorite uncle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen told him you were killed in  a hot tub accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intense) Dad was kidding, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the kid runs unexpectedly away, angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's two things to strangle  Stephen for. Where is he, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Stephen's not staying here now, Brian.  He moved out last April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An embarrassed sting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys ought to try picking up a  phone once in awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small one on the river. Several boats bob peacefully. E one. Raised high in dry-dock, it's an ancient fishing tra Bachman-Turner-Overdrive drifts up from the galley on bad fuzzed speakers as Brian climbs the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stripped to the waist, Stephen's bent-over cleaning out t guts of the inboard motor. He looks confused to see Brian

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked to Helen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong thing to say. Stephen turns back to his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Man, I thought dad's boat was  finally retired to the family  graveyard. Don't you worry about  falling out of this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen straightens up, his forearms smudged with grease. Brian admires the unwashed cereal bowls and peeling deck  paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like what you've done with the  place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's comin' along... want a beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen tosses him a beer from the fridge. As Brian pops he sees the small pile of city-issue gallon size cans in corner. Armorall, solvent, extinguisher foam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been ripping off fire stations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's old stuff Adcox gave me that  the department was going to throw  out anyway. Still good enough though  for this tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian winces at the music coming out of shot speakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bachman Turner Overdrive? (looks through music  rack) ...Buffalo Springfield?... Stephen  Bishop? Oh man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian lifts one of the tapes -- an 8-track -- and holds i carefully in his palm as if it were a rare and fragile re

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, an actual operating 8-track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you've never seen one before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the Field Museum once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It worked when you were in sixth  grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian opens the trunk of his old BMW. It's full of stereo boxes marked BRIAN'S "SOUND SPECTRUM".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian's gutted the speakers and is re-wiring them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People actually used to pay you for  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Millions, Stephen -- And sexual  favors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheep don't count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What about Laura --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was never proved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian moves over to another speaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you come here, Brian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to know why you messed with  my station assignment. I mean, is  this really gonna have to one of  those big brother -- little brother  "you broke my GI Joe and I'm still  pissed" games?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) What is it with you, man, huh? How  do you manage to keep coming up with  new and amazing ways to screw up?  That scotch bullshit? Am I really  supposed to believe you came crawling  back home because you suddenly felt  heart strings moan for the family  biz? You were bankrupt, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! You don't know me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you cold, Brian. The scary  thing is, you probably could have  faked it for awhile. But you see, in  this job there's no place to hide.  Isn't like selling log cabins. You  have a bad day here -- someone dies.  And that's not fucking good enough.  Want another beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's it? Big bad brother's gonna  ride my ass till I cough blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big bad brother is going to treat  you like any other probie -- that I  don't think is going to make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian staples the last of the audio cord in place and swi on the tape player. The cabin fills with sharp, crystal c Stephen Bishop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only so much technology can  do. (picks up his tool  box) Thanks for the beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the speakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian climbs down off the boat. Looks up at Stephen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, I told myself a million times  I didn't want to be a fireman. I  said bullshit to that line about  tradition and family legacy. I know  I split, and I know how you felt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know. You know what it  felt like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta do this, Stephen. I gotta  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're gonna find out, Brian.  Don't be late tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple one-room walk-up. A stereo blares Chicago blues Brian buttons up his uniform in the mirror. He steps back looks at himself, -- and oh man what the hell am I doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian climbs into his car, turns the key -- nothing. He g out, looks under the hood, then SLAMS it down in frustrat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pissed-off Chicago, hauling itself off to work in the  morning snap, passes by Brian's window. Tough Midwestern  brick. Tough Midwesterners. Heads-down in their 150 year with a wind committed to pushing the whole damn thing int Lake Michigan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train clacking away above him, Brian walks down the  sidewalk carrying his fire equipment. He turns a corner a comes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian stands there. It's his dad's station. Turn of the  century abused. Sooty with stone gargoyles and a pair of  faded red doors that suddenly CRANK OPEN as Brian comes u the drive. Fire engine 17 and ladder truck 46, lights  flashing, pull out onto the apron. The fireman sticking his head out of the passenger window Stephen. One look at the silver trumpet on his collar and know this isn't Fireman McCaffrey but Fire LT. McCaffrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too late, probie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim, in ladder truck 46, waves a small bye-bye as both ri begin heading down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chasing) Goddamn it, Stephen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian bolts full-out for the engine. At the last instant  before he falls on his face a fireman reaches out and dra him aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Adcox, the fireman from the first scene, now a veter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why baby McCaffrey, how ya doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pumper driver, SCHMIDT, pops in a howling ROCK TUNE a they zoom off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re Brian to Adcox) You know this rug rat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know him? I practically raised him. (Jewish mom) And he never calls, he never writes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian shouts over the noise to GRINDLE, 35, one more seat down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grindle sticks his nose out the window, sniffs, then begi buckling up his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, I do believe we have a  barbecue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Brian and Adcox fasten up their own equipment --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke pours with confused indecision from every window of five story factory as the pumper and ladder company pull

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at confusing  smoke) I hate it when we gotta fucking go  look for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Schmidt) Call in another alarm. We're gonna  need some back-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone begins strapping on air tanks and masks. Adcox d the rig's suction line to the hydrant. A beautiful illega parked Mercedes is blocking the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Stephen) Oh these moments do try me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admiring car) Be gentle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whistling to himself, Adcox SMASHES the brass coupling th the passenger window, runs the line through and SMASHES i out the other window before connecting up to the hydrant. Stephen and Grindle pull hose off the bed and move out.  Brian's so jacked up he can't get his air tank on right.  Schmidt calmly helps him into his gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only rock 'n roll, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen, Adcox and Grindle are crouched at the door, read to go. Brian takes a hose roll and runs to catch up when  he's cut-off by dazed Latin workers shouting incoherently him in SPANISH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, probie! How 'bout it, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian pushes past the workers and takes his position on t hose line. Stephen reaches over and re-adjusts Brian's ai tank strap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing it wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen eases the door open. Thick smoke rolls sickly out over their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brian) Stay beside me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in they go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the smoke is like liquid lead. Going by feel, they hump the hose up one staircase after another, crawling on their hands and knees toward a dull red glow. Turning a  corner, they enter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally ablaze. Brian looks up in wonder at the buffeting waves of flame in the ceiling, at the SCREECHING timbers  crumbling to the white-hot floor. At the walls HOWLING in bestial agony. It is the most horrifying, and wonderful t he has ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wash it to the windows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we'll hit the son of a bitch  head on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna flash, Stevie. We gotta  get behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, listen to it. It's a pussy.  It'll just steam on us. It won't  flash. Go high in the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adcox and Grindle shrug and pull their helmets down tight expecting the worst. Adcox opens up the nozzle, turning l a high pressure BLAST OF WATER into the ceiling. The fire SCREAMS in manic anger and HEAVES a cloud of HOWLING stea that WHIRLS back and BAKES them like lobsters. Brian gasp for air as swirling ash batters his facemask. A window  somewhere EXPLODES. Somebody shouts. Christ, you can't se anything. Stephen HOOPS in victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to fire) I knew you were a pussy! C'mon! Steam  us! (to firemen) Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chase is on! Going for the throat while the fire's  confused and defensive, the firemen SCRAMBLE through the  boiling cloud. They hit it in the ceiling, in the walls,  forcing it back and back. It HOWLS and CLAWS in anger,  furiously throwing cinders and broken timbers in their fa The walls ECHO with its SCREAMS as it retreats to a corne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya love it, probie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in heaven, Lt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hook us up to a stand-pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian runs back to the wall to hook up his hose roll to t building water system. He goes to unscrew the cap with hi hydrant wrench but it keeps slipping off the nut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, how 'bout man, huh? We're  gonna loose this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian finally gets it hooked up and runs back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim and three guys from his ladder company, come up an  extended aerial ladder, CRASH through a window and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: begin HACKING their way toward Brian's company as -- BOOM It's a sudden, shattering vibration that shakes the build to its foundations. Then, a sucking sound: RUSH-RUSH-RUSH Stephen speaks calmly into his radio handset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Otis, is it...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, where's our backup?  Where's the second-in companies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, man. John Wayne time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to firemen) Dig in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The firemen hesitate. PENGELLY, the Truck Company Lt., lo at Stephen with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dig in, goddamn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crews immediately gather in the center of the floor.  They turn over tables, chairs, anything to form a barrier circling of the wagons. -- BOOM! rush-rush-rush -- BOOM!  Each louder than the last. Stephen and Brian are ducked b an overturned desk. Adcox and Krizminski clutch hoselines like frontiersmen's Winchesters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna love this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- rush-rush-rush -- CRAAAASH!! On an instant the world c apart as all four walls of factory windows EXPLODE in a h of glass. A wave of HOWLING FLAME POURS IN after it, SHRI and HISSING. At the same moment, part of the floor beside a heavy sewi machine GIVES WAY and a ladderman, SANTOS, FALLS THROUGH, grabbing the edges at the last minute as flames BELLOW UP from underneath. He SCREAMS as his grip loosens. Grindle leaps to the ladderman's side, grabbing his arms coat. Brian hesitates just an instant and Stephen SHOVES out of the way to back up Grindle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help... Oh God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adcox's taken the hoseline and is opening fire. Water and flame crash and snarl across the floor in a blood curdlin ROAR. It's a thrashing, murderous standoff. Stephen and Grindle have got Santos but the angle's bad.  Blow it now and all three could take a header. Santos is  panicking, losing his grip. Grindle bores his eyes into t man's with the calm and conviction of Moses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go, we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They may all die, but they won't leave him. He calms a li hangs on till they PULL him out of harm's way. Adcox cont with the hose as suddenly, everyone HITS the deck as the  fire EXPLODES over them, BURSTING their coats into flame. Tim's company opens up their line, WASHING everybody down before CHARGING after the fire. A ladderman, NIGHTENGALE, steps on Brian's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry man, I thought you were dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, stunned, sits up, his coat and helmet smoking. Ste seems totally unaffected and is already on his feet and o the top of the barricade, the others backing him as he  mercilessly drives the fire back, trapping it finally int corner. The fire hisses, spits, shakes the walls with its furious anger. But it's all bluster now, the fire's dying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ladder co. captain) Stephen! BC's on the radio. Says  they think a civilian got left behind  downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adcox! Take Tim and do a search.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adcox leads Tim downstairs. Brian looks shaken up. Stephe helps him roughly to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you fold on me now, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian burns at that and shakes his brother's arm off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear the hose for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian's walking over to clear the hoseline when he hears small voice. Faint. "Help me..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I think it's coming from a  different staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody hears. -- Brian takes off down the other steps on own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only the fire's ghost here, lazy and slow. Off the corridor are rooms full of commercial sewing mach Brian enters one and drops to his knees. Looks under a table, flashes his light behind a work stan Nothing. He turns to backtrack his way out when A TONGUE FLAME suddenly LEAPS up through the floor in front of him cutting off the door. Brian lands on his ass as it hisses and giggles and dances unreally in front of him. I never forget a face, kid. -- That fire from childhood. could maybe force his way through but Jesus, the way it l at him -- -- Brian ROLLS away from it. Looks for another doorway -- And ends up in thick smoke. He drops to a crawl, stays on his belly where the air's clear. When he sees it. Behind  some furniture. Something flesh-colored. Shit. It's a bod He crawls up closer. It's a woman. Adrenalin pounding the top of his skull off, he grabs her and stumbles back down the hall, makes a turn --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And now he's bursting from the building onto a short f escape, shouting at the top of his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got somebody! I got somebody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sea of media flashbulbs ERUPTS in his face. The press h arrived in force, crowding the street. Brian pushes throu them to a clear spot on the far side of the engine. Two f paramedics rush over as he lowers the figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she... Is she alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The paramedics suddenly stop their efforts. Turn to Brian

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you're a little too late  with this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step aside. Brian looks down. The woman looks strang Mostly because she's a heavy store DRESSING DUMMY. The  paramedics burst into laughter. Brian, looking pale and  shaken, turns and walks away. He passes Grindle and Tim,  sitting on the pumper's tailboard helping the REAL woman  that was found inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear about the mannequin. I  heard you two were close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Photographers have appeared and are flashing the woman. D Brian wanders off, tries to help out with the choking clo of singed factory employees before finally turning quickl into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where he barfs his guts out in private. Doubled-over, one arm on the brick wall for support, we see the raw terror. The demons rushing out of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone else does too. Jennifer. Dressed now in a long  expensive coat, she's standing at the end of the alley wi a clipboard. Brian, ashes smeared across an ashen face,  spittle on his chin, doesn't notice her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appearing beside him) You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen isn't pale. He's flushed and buoyant. All this ha taken anything from him. It's made his day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Fine. I'm a little busy right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen leans against the wall. Folds his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, you got an awful short memory  for direct orders. I told you to  stay beside me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- C'mon, Stephen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You split the team, man. And what  was that crap with the standpipe?  You'd think you and a hose were never  introduced before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen turns to leave. Brian yells after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it Stephen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I told you to stay next to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I was doin' it! I was up there  fucking doin' it. You don't know,  man, you don't know what I did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you did was drop the ball,  Probie. Get that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from end of alley) Hey! Stevie! They're callin' for ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen turns to walk away. Pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet 30,000 dollars a year and twenty  two days a month off sounded pretty  good twelve weeks ago, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stephen leaves, we see that Jennifer's been standing a the end of the alley, listening to them. She's turns and  walks as Brian looks up. We register his surprise. He wat her head toward a dynamic-looking guy in his 40s, ALDERMA SWAYZAK, surrounded by reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to reporters) Roger, Paul... How's it going, guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another fire in this district. Getting  to be Cinder Alley up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking up) You used that last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands Swayzak a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling down from  window) (to Brian) Hey! Probie! We're still workin'  here, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian and the rest of the company rip open the walls and  beat the last weak flames in a final flurry of dingy spar The moment the smoke clears just a fraction, cigarettes a in everyone's mouth. Was it good for you? The talk is eas and obscene, the intense camaraderie of shared danger. As clods are thrown playfully back and forth in the afterglo of having taken on the worst there is and walking away on more time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Adcox) Stephen man, what's going through  that guy's head? Takin' it on in the  first room... this shit's happening  too often. It could've flashed.  Should've flashed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it didn't. Guy knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adcox sees Brian. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, baby McCaffrey. First one's the  clincher. You did okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Lt. might have something to say  about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, everybody screws up some, Brian.  You're working for the toughest Lt.  on the job. Saw him once pick up a  probie he thought was moving too  slow and throw him into a burning  building. It's just bad luck you're  family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) John, when you're in there... in the  fire... do you ever see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from across room,  interrupting) C'mon ladies, let's roll some hose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Adcox) -- Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian turns and sees out the window Jennifer and Swayzak  standing near Rimgale's red fire dept. sedan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rimgale walks up to his sedan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alderman Swayzak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Investigator Rimgale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to get in the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swayzak's leaning on it. We sense the dislike between the Swayzak steps aside. Rimgale pops the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awful expensive shoes to be wearing  at a fireground, Alderman. But then  I guess you haven't been to too many  fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to you about Alan  Seagrave's death. We still haven't  gotten a fire report from your office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have an answer as soon as I  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are asking how a prominent  taxpayer got stuffed through the  windshield of his own car. They're  asking me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --The point is, Investigator, you  haven't even told us yet if the fire  was accidental. We're starting to  get the feeling your office is  dragging out this case to embarrass  the Alderman because of his fire  dept. reorganization program --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You mean his firehouse closing  program, -- Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd just be very disappointed if it  turned out your office was playing  politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Because I'm not. I care about  this city, and I care about this  department --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rimgale cuts him off with the shutting of his trunk lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm of a monk) Alderman, I have a remarkably  uncomplicated job. To decide if a  fire's arson, and if so catch the  pain in the ass doing it. But to be  honest, if my methodical investigative  methods just happen to muck up the  campaign of certain mayor wanna-bees,  well, I guess I can't say I sleep  any less peacefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he walks back to the burned building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could just fire the son of  a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Swayzak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen's leaning out of an upstairs window. As the TV ca turn, he drops down onto a fire engine hose bed and pops  right into Swayzak's face with a murderous grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We almost lost a whole company up  there, Swayzee buddy. Isn't any back- up since you closed '33. And we really  appreciate it, the guys and me.  Honest. I know you've got my vote  for mayor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grindle and Santos start walking for Stephen. Brian's the following after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look Lt., I'm on your side. If there's  a problem, please, work with our  task force to fix it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, your famous task force...  three guys have already died this  year because of the cuts made by  your "task force"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevie, c'mon man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen silences Grindle with an outstretched hand. Swayz leans close, out of earshot of the cameras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see that funny glow that's  starting to blink in the corner of  your eye, Lt? That's your career  dissipation light -- and it just  went into overtime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anybody's light's gonna blink,  it's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swayzak holds his ground. It's a tense, out of control mo between them. Rimgale turns from his work, watches Stephe with concern. Adcox suddenly inserts himself face-to-face with Swayzak and we see the raw hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in firemanland now, Swayzak.  Do yourself a favor and just walk  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swayzak holds Adcox's gaze, then turns for his car. Brian watches Jennifer climb in beside her boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your city job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer shrugs as they pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian jumps down from the rig as it backs up the driveway Across the street a middle-aged woman flashes them from t balcony of her apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Franny. She likes firemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim, fill out the alarm card. (to Brian) Clean the pipe poles, wipe down the  ladders and hang some hose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adcox watches Brian and Tim exchange looks. Tim shrugs. B sighs and pulls out the pike poles, starts across the flo before freezing suddenly at a murderous GROWL. Brian turn and sees a DOG. Sort of. It has the rib cage of a wild be fangs, long greasy hair. It blocks his way, SNARLING with hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's The Thing. You can't stay  unless he likes you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slobber drools out of its mouth as it GROWLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you guys got something against  dalmatians?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian wipes some of the crusted grime from his face, look back and forth between Franny and The Thing, and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian enters, strips down his battered uniform, and opens his locker. The mannequin from the fire SPRINGS OUT, legs spread. A sign taped to its mouth says: "TAKE ME BRIAN, Y

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian and the others scrub the morning's fire off their b in the station shower. Tim keeps filling his mouth full o water and launching it upward in a stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pumped) Could you believe that fire? Man!  First day! There I was, Adcox and  me, pullin' that lady right out of  the fire's fuckin' throat! I love it  here -- No surround and drown for  this company. Fighting 17th! Goddamn  Stephen's amazing. You see how he  took that fire by the balls? I'm  gonna be that good some day, you  watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian compares himself to the praise heaped on Stephen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know what Stephen said to me, right  when all the shit was coming hard?  "You never know till the moment the  fire stares you down if you're just  gonna do this job or be great at  it".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah man, is he usin' that line now on  you? What, you think he made that  little gem up? Jesus Christ, I used  to have to listen to my old man use  that every morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian shuts off his shower and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen sits alone at his bunk, slowly stretching a strai and ruined back. He blows out a long, tired breath, and b working ointment into an anciently scarred and battered k On the wall is a small glass case full of station memorab through the years. There's a two battered fire helmets th set reverently on velvet. Beside it is a photograph of hi father. Grinning. Top of the world. He's wearing a T-shir proudly stenciled FIGHTING 17th. Father and son exchange a long, awkward greeting. In the doorway, Brian stands watching his brother, who no even 40, suddenly seems an old and broken man. The ALARM KLAXON suddenly sounds. Brian, just in a towel Tim, in boxers covered with little dinosaurs, dash for th fire pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim and Brian slide down and bounce off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- C'mon! C'mon! Go! Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian and Tim rush for their equipment. Grindle grabs the arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! C'mon! This way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hustles them across the apparatus floor, through a doo and into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The makings of a meal are laid out on the counter. Brian Tim come to a screeching halt. The rest of the station is sitting calmly at the kitchen table, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner, Probies. Get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim and Brian, still in their boxers, set down plates of  food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or we feed you to The Thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody digs in. The table is a craze of half a dozen  different conversations. On the TV mounted above on the w are news shots of Seagrave's body sticking out of the  windshield. Adcox stands and tinks his glass with a spoon for silence

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, please... As 17's official  toastmaster --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And bullshitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Santos. Did I happen to  mention that you were cut out of my  will? (company laughs) I think it appropriate that we  recognize the two asswipes -- I mean  probationary firemen -- among us who  today were baptized officially into  the world of Old Man Fire. First to  Tim, who despite being handicapped  at birth with a rather dull expression  and a really hideous pair of ears,  not only took on the beast but pulled  from its clutches -- assisted by a  more famous and brilliant firefighter --  me -- a kicking and screaming civilian  that will probably end up suing us  for breaking her fingernail. (laughs) And to Brian, who's own contribution  was both more beautiful and less  likely to sue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adcox puts his arm affectionately around the mannequin, s with honor at the head of the table. Right beside The Thi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, when I heard that both  McCaffrey brothers were going to be  assigned together here, well, my  heart was filled with... a sudden  desire to transfer. (laughs) So raise a glass, lads. To funny- looking Tim, and the McCaffrey  brothers, who despite years of getting  on each other's nerves have managed  with great effort... to still be  pissed off at each other. Gentlemen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (together, a toast) Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The klaxon suddenly rings. Two bells. The ladder guys gro and get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winks) We'll keep it warm for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn lightens the room as Brian slowly opens his eyes and sees in extreme, fish-eyes close-up: THE THING GROWLING a him. Brian turns the other direction and sees Stephen, fu dressed, standing over his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean the toilets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleary-eyed, the nine firemen line up raggedly in front o their rigs, dressed like shit but for peaked uniform caps they wear only at this moment. Stephen stands before them does a quick glance up and down the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, company dismissed. -- See ya  guys tonight at Fitzgerald's  retirement party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shuffle for the door. As Brian passes,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen pulls up. Brian opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian -- (a beat that hangs  there) -- See ya tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's been cleared out for a huge PARTY in full swing. A Irish folk band cuts loose a merciless bagpipe beat. City brass--including Alderman Swayzak -- a few reporters, fir and their families all mix together for this is a RETIREM PARTY for the Captain Fitzgerald. Brian enters, seeks out beer at the bar. Stephen's there, swaying with what is cl not his first drink of the evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHEERS as a one joke gift after another is laid on the Ch Stephen sees his ex-wife, Helen, dancing with another man He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta change the view...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santos and Grindle walk up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard you didn't make the list for  captain, man. I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen just shrugs. Brian sees Jennifer across the room. She looks great. Ref as she expertly works the room, schmoozing and hugging an calling various politicos by their first name. As she speaks to one, a waiter offers a drink. As she acc a bottle appears over her shoulder and splashes it with r syrup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding bottle,  interrupting) With grenadine, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooh, very sophisticated. Having  fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her attention broken, the politico has slipped away. Anno Jennifer leads Brian aside and speaks low, but angrily at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm not the same girl who had  nothing better to do than wrap her  legs around you on a Saturday night.  This isn't about fun. I'm working  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying Swayzak's notebook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something. Martin  Swayzak is going to be this town's  next mayor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Swayzak. Humanity's last hope.  How can you work for that guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think Marty came here  tonight? Because he cares about your  department. You don't know how hard  he works. You don't know about his  programs helping West Side --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- All I know is that his programs  are getting firemen hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Marty's plan is only about  efficiency. I've got two cousins on  the job, you think I'd work for him  if I didn't believe in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer instantly cuts off as a well-dressed COUPLE pass and switches stunningly into schmmoze-mode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to man) -- Tom, how nice to see you. I know  Marty'll be very happy you came.  Thanks so much for the donation. (to woman) Marie... how's little Kevin? Really?  Seen the polls? This is the year...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move away. Jennifer turns to Brian and switches just fast back to their argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- The thing that really makes me  angry is the way your union has --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian can't help it. He cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that? Oh man, you have picked  up a few moves since John Paul II  Boulevard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I like to think I'm just  a little past hanging out on JP II  watching the Irish pick fights and  Litwalks barf in the planters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seem to remember some pretty good  nights on JP II.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Adcox is talking with another knot of firemen. He's broug a date, SALLY, a hot little number that has a habit of  standing on her tip-toes when she talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Swayzak  across room) Yuck, what a scumbag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Santos) Fuckin' city transferred Sally three  months ago out of parking violations  into Swayzak's office. Now I gotta  pay my own goddamn tickets and she's  stuck with an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) No, but there's more exercise --  being chased around a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a commotion at the other end of the bar. A group firemen have gathered around a weekly magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, I don't believe this shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody get a shovel! You seen this,  Stephen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they hold it up to Stephen we see a photo spread title DARING FIRE RESCUE. The first photo shows Brian rushing out of the burning  building with seemingly a woman in his arms. The second p shows the backs of Adcox and Tim's helmets as they  administered aid to the real woman they saved. The implic is it's the same woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads) "Probationary Fireman Brian McCaffrey,  on his very first fire, showed the  kind of bravery and courage of a  veteran firefighter when he risked  life and limb to double-check a  burning floor alone, emerging  victoriously with Anna Rodriguez, a  seamstress for the North Shore  Clothing Company... McCaffrey first  gained prominence as the subject of  a 1972 Pulitzer Prize winning  photograph taken at the scene of his  father's death..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old photo is there too. Brian and his dad's helmet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whadda we gonna do about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen glances over the headlines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, I think it's a union bylaw  that if a guy gets in the paper --  especially if it's bullshit -- he  owes the company a drink. In fact... (motions to waiter) ...I'll have a double. On the hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other firemen jump in with drink orders. Dozens of th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim shows him the magazine. Brian reads with horror as  Alderman Swayzak appears beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian McCaffrey, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, this is my boss, Alderman  Swayzak. (to Swayzak) Brian's a big fan of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Big fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm a huge fan of what you did  to save that woman, Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I think there's been a mistake.  I didn't save that woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to be modest, Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't understand, I saved a  mannequin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- That really was incredibly work  you did. You and your brother,  fighting fires together, helluva  image, isn't it? You must feel lucky  to be assigned under his command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every little boy's fantasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, let me come to the point. I'd  like to offer you a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's still with the fire  department. One of our best  investigators, Don Rimgale, is working  on a very difficult, visible case  right now. We think he could use  another pair of hands and you're  exactly the kind of guy I want  representing us: An authentic hero  from a traditional firefighting clan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we got all kinds of traditions -- like dying young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not every job in the fire department  comes with a tombstone, Brian. This  could be a great opportunity to  move... beyond a fire engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian looks at Jennifer, then smiles at Swayzak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks anyway, Mr. Swayzak, but fire  engines sorta run in my family.  Politics don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- A man suddenly steps between them to pump Swayzak's ha Brian shakes his head and walks away. Swayzak shoots a  concerned glance at Jennifer. She catches up with him at buffet table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, took you all of thirty seconds  to blow that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon Jennifer, he's just another  North-Side jag-off with a mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, do you always have to be so  stupid? Think about your future for  once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now you suddenly care about my  future?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I didn't mean to take a piece  out of you back there, I just thought  you'd call when you came back. You  didn't and... (beat) Don't blow it just because of this  garbage between us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, sorry if I made you look bad in  front of your boss. But I'm not gonna  be a poster boy for him, I'm trying  to do something here. There's five  hundred smoke eaters in this room  that do that stuff for real every  day. Tell Swayzak to talk to one of  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the room, Stephen's at the buffet, watching Helen  dance with her fireman date, the drinks hammering him har

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw man, how can she dance with that  guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate that guy. He's a dispatcher.  I hate his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I know women have gotta bang  somebody, but why that son of a bitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen gives Pengelly an icy, sideways look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Stevie, he's an asshole...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen smiles and pushes off the bar -- right for Helen she dances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Helen, I wanted to talk to you a  second about Sean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen, I'm kinda busy here, can we  talk about this later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doin', Stephen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson steers her away but Stephen isn't done yet. He do them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Helen) What's wrong with right now? He's  your son for christ's sake. He's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Stephen, what about that dumb  ass brother of yours, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Savin' a mannequin... How fuckin'  stupid can a guy get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen suddenly PUNCHES Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't talk about my brother like  that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Here we go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Stephen PLOWS into Jackson. Another fireman JUMPS to  Jackson's aid. And Brian's there, defending his brother,  PUNCHING OUT a fireman. The crowd finally pulls the two a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, Stephen, lay off! (Stephen calms a little) You stupid dumbshit, you never know  when to fucking quit, do you? You  ever wonder why your career's in the  fucking toilet? Why you're gonna be  stuck a Lt. for life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (beat) I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen takes a step for the bar -- then suddenly turns a JUMPS Jackson again. Brian pulls him off and drags him fo the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need a drink, man. You  need to get outta here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jennifer watches Brian lead Stephen out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Swayzak) Ah those McCaffreys... just hate  leaving a party with anyone left  standing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian leads Stephen toward his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay... leave me alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen pushes Brian away and promptly stumbles to the  sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you got a 'roid going with Jackson  or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, he's nothin'. It's just  sometimes... sometimes you just gotta  punch somebody out, y'know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian stands there and folds his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I can get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian lends an arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Brian, a photographer. Maybe I  can get on the cover of LIFE magazine,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, let's crawl home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen throws an arm over Brian's shoulder as he leads h up onto the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Adcox, those guys...they don't  get it... it isn't the goddamn  promotion... or dad... I'm not my  old man, y'know? No fire's gonna get  me... I don't give a shit about being  a captain... it's just... it's just  they don't trust me anymore... (blows out painful  breath) ...they don't trust me anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian's flops his brother on the bed. Unties his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd get out of my fuckin' way.  I could take my own goddamn shoes  off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clearly can't. Brian slips them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're such a pain in the ass...  You've always been a pain in the  ass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just a grim wall lamp above Stephen's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, it's too damn bright in here...  Like a goddamn spotlight... I'm goin'  blind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching light) This?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... too bright...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
